headline.main: THE WARD TRAGEDY.; The Trial of the Brothers Ward in Kentucky.

docs.lead_paragraph: From the Cincinnati Enquirer, April 21. The trial of MATHEW F. WARD and ROBERT WARD for murder of Mr. H. G. BUTLER, is creating considerable excitement in Louisville. The case commenced on Tuesday morning at Elizabethtown, and a severance granted, MATHEW being first placed on trial.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sam. Slick, in his renowned Sayings and Doings, tells a story of an old Indian coming into a country store for some liquor. "Why, Big-elk-skin," said the storekeeper, " seems to me you have had too much already."
docs.snippet: Sam. Slick, in his renowned Sayings and Doings, tells a story of an old Indian coming into a country store for some liquor. "Why, Big-elk-skin," said the storekeeper, " seems to me you have had too much already."

docs.lead_paragraph: REMOVAL OF MARKETS.--The Committee on Markets of the Board of Councilmen met at No. 4 Hall of Records yesterday, at 3 o'clock, GIDEON CLIFTON in the Chair, for the purpose of hearing arguments for and against the removal of Washington and Catharine Markets.

docs.lead_paragraph: HISTORY OF THE FRENCH PROTESTANT REFUGEES, from the Revocation of the Edict of Na??tes to our own day. By M. CHARLES WEISS, Professor of History in the Lycee Bonapario. Translated from the French by HENRY WILLIAM HERBERT, with an American Appendix, by a descendant of the Huguenots. 2 vols. pp. 382, 410. New-York: STRINGER TOWNSEND.
